plugins.name: Simple inspector
plugins.description:
CSS Extractor is a Figma plugin designed to help developers quickly extract CSS styles from selected elements and their children. It supports nested structures, text styles, image fills, and allows for easy image export. The UI provides options to copy the entire style block or individual style lines.


Key Features:


üîç Display of selected elements and their child hierarchy.


üé® Conversion of styles to CSS with unit selection: px or rem.

plugins.name: i18n JSON exporter
plugins.description:
Escape the time-consuming manual localization work and costly third-party tools with their cumbersome plugins. Leverage the power of Figma variables for efficient i18n.


Simply use your Design System or a central library file to create i18n keys, and then effortlessly export them for development with this plugin.


Step 1

Setup your Figma variables. Create a collection, add a columns (modes) for each language you wish to localize.


Not a step

Use those variables to replace your labels, input placeholders and more. Then use the "Appearance > Apply variable mode" to switch between languages (modes). I suggest having an "ID" mode with the i18n keys, like $general.table.label_lastModified.


Step 2

Run this plugin, select a collection and modes desired, then click "Export JSON file".


Note

This plugin uses the variable group path to create a hierarchical structure in the exported JSON. For example, a variable named general / table / label_lastModified would be exported as:


{
"general": {
"table": {
"label_lastModified": "Last modified"
}
}
}


Future features

Leave comments to vote on the following features I planned and what features you would like to see on this plugin.

  1. Github Merge Request integration
  2. Support to different JSON formats
  3. Transformation capabilities
plugins.tagline: Effortlessly export your Figma i18n variables to a React-compatible JSON format

plugins.name: Create Red Rectangle Plugin
plugins.description:
Objective: Implement functionality where clicking a button creates a red rectangle on the workspace.


Implementation Plan:


Creating the Interface:


Add a button labeled "Create Rectangle."

Prepare a canvas or container where the rectangle will appear.

Styling Elements:


Define styles for the button (e.g., color, shape).

Set default dimensions and properties for the rectangle (e.g., width, height, background color).

Programming Logic:


Write an event handler for the button: on click, create an element with predefined properties (e.g., width, height, color).

Append this element to the container on the page.

Testing the Functionality:


Ensure the red rectangle appears correctly and only when the button is clicked.

Optionally, add features such as slightly offsetting the position of each new rectangle.
plugins.tagline: Rectangle

plugins.name: SpeX - Design to Code by AI
plugins.description:
SpeX ‚Äì Design to Code by AI


Transform your Figma components into AI-readable specs for seamless design-to-code automation.


üîç What is SpeX?

SpeX bridges design and development by exporting structured specifications from Figma‚Äîenabling AI tools like Cursor and GitHub Copilot to generate accurate, production-grade UI code that aligns with your actual components.


üéØ Who It's For

  1. Design system teams scaling reusable components
  2. Developers using AI coding assistants
  3. Product teams aiming for consistent handoffs
  4. Organizations enforcing structured design workflows


üöÄ Key Capabilities


üìã AI-Ready Export

  1. Export to YAML/JSON with full style tokens
  2. Support nested components, variants, and instances
  3. Auto-detect and optimize SVG icons
  4. Generate component preview thumbnails


üîß Fine-Tuning Metadata

  1. Add codeComponent and codeFilePath
  2. Auto-fill metadata via pattern recognition
  3. Visual tree browser with search and bulk editing


üóÉ Component Record Management

  1. Full CRUD for structured records
  2. Sync from Notion, APIs, or JSON files
  3. Filterable views with fallback thumbnails
  4. Export component registry as JSON


ü§ñ Real-Time AI Integration

  1. WebSocket-based MCP bridge for tools like Cursor AI
  2. Real-time dashboard and analytics
  3. Serve specs, manifest, and previews on-demand
  4. Auto-reconnect and error resilience


üß≠ How It Works

  1. Select Components ‚Äì from your Figma file
  2. Fine-Tune ‚Äì add mappings to your codebase (optional)
  3. Export or Connect ‚Äì structured file export or live MCP server
  4. Generate Code ‚Äì AI tools use the specs to write code that aligns with your system


üìÅ Output Structure (Simplified)

export-[timestamp]/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ screen.yaml # Main screen specs
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ manifest.yaml # File manifest
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/ # Component specs
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ styles/ # Design token definitions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ icons/ # SVG exports
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ previews/ # PNG previews


Example screen.yaml

# screen.yaml
screen:
id: "signup-screen-001"
name: "SignupForm"
type: "FRAME"

dimensions:
width: 375
height: 812

styleRefs:
fills:
- "@styles/fills#background-default"
typography:
- "@styles/typography#body-normal"

children:
- type: "INSTANCE_REF"
ref: "@components/TextField#username-field-001"
- type: "INSTANCE_REF"
ref: "@components/TextField#email-field-002"
- type: "INSTANCE_REF"
ref: "@components/TextField#password-field-003"
- type: "INSTANCE_REF"
ref: "@components/Button#signup-button-001"
- type: "INSTANCE_REF"
ref: "@components/TextLink#login-link-001"


This defines a form-based screen layout with multiple input fields, a button, and a link‚Äîreferencing reusable components in the design system.


üîó spex-mcp

Install the companion server to integrate with AI dev tools:

‚Üí spex-mcp on npm


üí° Why SpeX?


For Designers

  1. Reduce handoff friction
  2. Track design usage across implementations


For Developers

  1. Avoid guesswork, get exact specs
  2. Leverage AI tools with full context


For AI Tools

  1. Access structured, hierarchical data
  2. Align generated code with real-world components


SpeX is where design systems meet automation. Your components. Your rules. Real code.
plugins.tagline: Built on your real components, not generic templates.

plugins.name: Figma Recall
plugins.description:
This plugin lets you save, manage, and switch between different versions (iterations) of your Figma frames.


Save an Iteration: Select a frame and click the Save button to save its current state.


Save with a Note: Hold Ctrl/Cmd and click the Save button to add a text description to your saved iteration.


Recall All Iterations: Select a frame and click the Recall button to view all its saved versions side-by-side.


Update Iterations: Make changes in the recalled container frame for any version and click Save to update with your changes in the stored master versions.


Navigate Versions: Use the < and > arrow buttons to cycle through saved iterations directly on your canvas.


Delete All Iterations: Select a frame and click the Delete button (trash icon) to remove all its saved versions.


Rename Iterations: Right-click the Save button to rename the selected frame and its entire group of saved iterations.
plugins.tagline: Version History but for Each Frame

plugins.name: Frame Navigator
plugins.description:
üß≠ FrameNavigator


Effortlessly navigate large and complex Figma files with FrameNavigator ‚Äî a floating Table of Contents plugin that helps you stay organized and move between frames in a single click.


‚ú® Key Features


- Quick Navigation

Instantly jump to any frame from a floating panel that stays visible while you work.


- Custom Frame Registration

Select frames directly on the canvas and add them to your TOC with a simple "+" button.


- Group Organization

Organize your frames into custom groups for better structure and clarity‚Äîperfect for managing multiple screens.


- Flexible Panel Sizes

Choose between default, compact, and full views to match your workflow and screen space.


---


üõ† How It Works


  1. Register a Frame: Select a frame on the Figma canvas and click the `+` button in the plugin to add it to the TOC.
  2. Create a Group: Hover over ungrouped frames in the TOC and click the appearing checkbox to select them. Then click the Create Group button at the top of the panel to group them.
  3. Add to Existing Group: Select a group first, then select a new frame on the canvas and click `+` to add the frame into that group.
  4. Rename a Group: Double-click on a group name to edit it.
  5. Remove a Group: Right-click on a group and select **Remove Group**. ‚ö†Ô∏è Note: All frames inside that group will also be removed from the TOC.
  6. Reorder Frames: Drag and drop frames (or groups) within the TOC to change their order.


---


Perfect for design system creators, large prototyping flows, or anyone managing multi-screen layouts in Figma.
plugins.tagline: Quickly jump between frames with a floating table of contents. Easily build your own TOC.

plugins.name: Change Variable Descriptions
plugins.description:
Tired of manually updating each Figma variable‚Äôs description? This plugin streamlines the process by allowing you to update all variable descriptions simultaneously using a CSV file. This means you can ensure your design system stays consistent and well-documented‚Äîwithout the hassle of repetitive edits.


How It Works:


‚Ä¢Prepare Your CSV: Create a CSV file with the format: token_name,description. Ensure each variable name in your CSV matches exactly (1:1) with the ones in Figma; the plugin is sensitive to misspellings and will skip any mismatches.

‚Ä¢Select Variable Collection(s): Choose one or multiple variable collections based on your CSV file. (Recommendation: create a separate CSV for each collection.)

‚Ä¢Preview Changes: Review the highlighted changes in a table before applying them, ensuring accuracy and control over the update process.

‚Ä¢Apply Updates: With just a few clicks, update all selected variable descriptions in your Figma design system.


Streamline your design documentation, avoid manual errors, and keep your design tokens up-to-date effortlessly!
plugins.tagline: Simplify workflow: Update variable descriptions in one click

plugins.name: Move Outside
plugins.description:
A plugin designed to move any elements outside of their current frames and place them at the top of the hierarchy while retaining their original position relative to the entire page. The plugin offers two modes:


  1. Default - Moves selected single or multiple elements to the top of the page‚Äôs layer hierarchy.
  2. Locked Target - Moves selected single or multiple elements into another specified layer. The Locked Target mode supports moving into frames, frames with autolayout, and sections. If the Locked Target is an autolayout frame, users can choose whether the moved frames should retain their original page position using absolute positioning or adapt to the autolayout.


This plugin stands out from others with similar functionality by offering a full interface that enables continuous management of complex layer structures.
plugins.tagline: A plugin used to move elements to the top of the layer hierarchy or to other frames/sections.

plugins.name: Lint copy
plugins.description:
Lint copy helps UX writers and content designers automatically enforce style rules with a custom word list.


Enforce things like plain language (e.g. detect "utilize" and suggest replacing it with "use"), the company's voice and tone (e.g. detect "we are" and suggest using the contraction), and even product terminology.


Create a custom word list in JSON and host it in a public GitHub repository to experience the plugin's full power.


The plugin also enforces sentence case and strings starting with a capital, neither of which is customizable.


For full details, read the documentation.
plugins.tagline: Check text layers against a word list to enforce style, voice, and terminology.

plugins.name: Remote Variable Replacer
plugins.description:
Sometimes Figma variables aren‚Äôt coming from inside the house. While this plugin has a likely very tiny amount of potential users, if I can help anybody save any time trying to locate and replace variables that are orphans or ‚Äúremote‚Äù, then this has been worth it.


For whatever reason, variables in Figma can be attached to other libraries, older files, archived files even. This can cause major headaches when editing local variables and components don‚Äôt seem to respond to the edits.


I fully expect this plugin to have a limited lifespan as Figma themselves will likely improve variable handling during copy/pastes, schema renaming or other scenarios where variables can be orphaned.


In the meantime, I got you.
plugins.tagline: Replace those pesky remote variables!

For whatever reason, variables in Figma can be attached to other libraries, older files, archived files even. This can cause major headaches when editing local variables and components don‚Äôt seem to respond to the edits.


I fully expect this plugin to have a limited lifespan as Figma themselves will likely improve variable handling during copy/pastes, schema renaming or other scenarios where variables can be orphaned.


In the meantime, I got you.
135284.release_notes:
Improved the dropdowns for numerical variables to only show local variables whose base value match the remote variable base value. This should make the plugin easy to navigate if a user has hundreds of variables.

Removed beta language; Included network access for tailwind for easy stying and unpkg.com for React. This should fix the blank screen of death. Rookie mistake!

Also updated the data security details to let users know the network access is only for static items.

plugins.name: Pseudo Localizer for Figma & FigJam
plugins.description:
Design global-ready UIs‚Äîwithout ever leaving Figma.


Skip the guesswork and see how your designs hold up in other languages, scripts, and text directions‚Äîinstantly. With Pseudo Localizer, you can preview localized versions of your UI in seconds, directly inside Figma or FigJam. No setup, no logins, no external tools. Just you and your design.


‚ÑπÔ∏è What you can do with Pseudo Localizer:


‚úÖ Preview global scripts instantly

Toggle between Latin, Cyrillic, CJK, and Arabic (RTL) with a single click.


‚úÖ Test layout resilience

Stretch or shrink text length from ‚Äì50% to +50% to spot issues like clipping, wrapping, or misalignment.


‚úÖ Control the scope

Run it on a single button, a card, or the whole page‚Äîyour call.


‚úÖ Keep it private & fast

Everything happens on your machine. No accounts, no external servers, no privacy worries.


‚ùóÔ∏èWhy it matters:


  1. Catch layout issues before they become bugs.
  2. Give your QA and localization teams better previews.
  3. Design smarter for a global audience‚Äîright from the start.


‚öôÔ∏è How it works:


  1. Select your screens with text layers (or don't select anything to pseudo translate the full page).
  2. Pick your script and text expansion.
  3. Click "Pseudotranslate"‚Äîdone! A new page appears with your mocked-up, localized content (including RTL adjustments).


‚ú® Ready to build for every language?

Install Pseudo Localizer from the Figma Community and see how your designs hold up across the globe.


üì® Got feedback? Share it here!

plugins.name: Lokki - Comments Export
plugins.description:
Description

A plugin that allows you to turn Figma comments into Jira tasks with a couple of clicks.


Key features

- Export comments to selected Jira project

- Filter comments

- Merge multiple comments into one.

- Turn comment into sub-issue of the existing Jira issue.


How to use

When you run the plugin, it offers a simple 3 step onboarding screen explaining how things work.

  1. During the first run, we'll ask you to connect your plugin with your Jira.
  2. Next you need to generate personal token that allows you access your comments. This is mandatory for plugins operation since Figma do not provide direct access to comments with figma plugin tools.
  3. Select Jira project that you will use as default. You can change it later.
  4. That's it. You can select comments and export them to the Jira.


Sidenote

This is our first-ever plugin on Figma, and while things might not be ideal all at once, we are happy to hear your feedback, questions, and suggestions at dev@lokki.tools

Webpage: https://lokki.tools


Data Security & Network access

Our plugin does not save any remote counterpart, it means your data is only stored on your computer, inside your Figma editor. This applies to all of your data, tokes and comments except user identifier related to the premium status and subscription info.


About

- Idea by Kseniia Pashkovska & Oleksandr Drobinin

- Implementation by Oleksandr Drobinin

plugins.name: UnfigShadow
plugins.description:
UnfigShadow - Advanced Shadowing for Figma is a professional plugin that brings realistic, multi-layered shadow generation into your design workflow. Unlike Figma‚Äôs native shadow tools, this plugin lets you control shadow distance, direction, blur, opacity decay, steps, and color‚Äîall through a clean and intuitive interface.


Create complex light and depth effects in seconds without needing to manually stack shadow layers. Ideal for UI/UX designers, component libraries, and anyone seeking to add realistic depth to their interfaces.

plugins.name: ShadeSmith ‚Äì AI Palette Generator
plugins.description:
ShadeSmith is a Figma plugin that helps designers and developers instantly create scalable color palettes from a single base color (500-level).

It automatically generates tints, shades, and tonal variations using intelligent color logic. Whether you‚Äôre working on a design system, branding kit, or just experimenting, ShadeSmith ensures visually consistent and WCAG-compliant palettes with every click.


‚ú® Features:

‚Ä¢Start from any hex/RGB/base color

‚Ä¢Instantly generate tints (100‚Äì400) and shades (600‚Äì900)

‚Ä¢Accessible contrast suggestions built-in

‚Ä¢Copy-ready output for Figma styles, Tailwind tokens, or CSS

‚Ä¢Customizable intensity and range sliders


Perfect for:

‚Ä¢Design systems

‚Ä¢Theming

‚Ä¢Light/dark mode variants

‚Ä¢Rapid prototyping
